history.content:
126 is a class more focused on the fundamentals than the applications (hence why it is recommended to be taken first). The class probably won't help much when it comes to things that are industry relevant. However, if you're interested in taking more advanced machine learning courses or doing research, it is a very good idea. The class is also very interesting in terms of the variety of concepts covered.

----

I also took 126 after getting an A in 189 and found it a totally new beast. Would recommend if you have any interest in pursuing further graduate coursework (almost all of which will require a good grade in 126) or research.

126 is a class more focused on the fundamentals than the applications (hence why it is recommended to be taken first). The class probably won't help much when it comes to things that are industry relevant. However, if you're interested in taking more advanced machine learning courses or doing research, it is a very good idea. The class is also very interesting in terms of the variety of concepts covered.

children.subject: Since you already know about EM algorithm, MLE, MAP, HMMs, Discrete time markov chains and the Viterbi algorithm, and you have gotten an A post-189, then I would suggest not taking 126, unless you really want to just practice and reinforce what you already know. Honestly, you aren't going to learn much more in 126 if you already know the aforementioned topics.

history.content: I finished 189 this semester and got an A. I have not yet taken 126 or 127, and I am wondering if it would be helpful for me to take 126. I did familiarize myself with the material of 126 before taking 189. I am very comfortable with multivariate gaussians/random vectors from 189. I would say I have a pretty decent understanding of topics like the Kalman Filter, the EM algorithm, MLE, MAP, HMMs, Discrete time markov chains and the Viterbi algorithm from 188, 70 and from prepping for 189. Would taking 126 be worth it post 189 with an A level understanding of the 189 material (and given my background)? I have no intention of doing signal processing or robotics, and I will likely end up doing SWE or maybe ML/data science. Would 126 be helpful for SWE-esque jobs (like for navigation algorithm stuff)? And does 126 focus enough on the application topics (like the algorithms/topics mentioned above) to be directly useful in industry, or is it better for just nailing the fundamentals?
history.subject: usefulness of 126 post 189
